results.title: Entertaining angels
results.creator_credit: Michael Rhodes, Elwood Kieser and Paulist Pictures
results.brief_description: ‘Entertaining Angels’ is based on the true life of Dorothy Day, a radical journalist who lived in New York writing about the plight of America’s homeless. She has an early love affair with a co-worker which results in a traumatic abortion that sees her move to the coast to be alone. While staying at the beach Dorothy (Moira Kelly) comes across and old friend and the two fall in love. It is at this time that Dorothy begins to question her faith after some close contact with one of the nuns who runs a shelter for the disadvantaged. Dorothy falls pregnant to Foster and although happy for a while, she refuses to give up her religion and he refuses to marry, once again Dorothy is alone but ready to move back to the city. Dorothy and her daughter are baptized Catholics and Dorothy resumes her career as a journalist, only this time starting her own paper, “The Catholic Worker” after meeting Peter, a French social activist. Dorothy combines her journalism and charity at home, offering the homeless a soup kitchen, shelter and office where she can work on the paper. This is an inspiring film that was made on a relatively small budget by Paulist Pictures who also brought us ‘Romero’.

results.title: Ennui = L'Ennui [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Cedric Kahn, Paolo Branco, Canal+, Centre National de la Cinematographie, Gemini Films, Ima Films and Madragoa Filmes
results.brief_description: Martin is a philosopher suffering from ennui - listless at work, disinterested in films or literature, disenchanted with life and estranged from his ex-wife. One night he meets an elderly painter, who dies shortly afterwards whilst making love to his teenage muse, Cecilia. Intrigued by Cecilia’s hold over the artist (who painted her obsessively) Martin starts to meet Cecilia every afternoon for uncommitted sex. At first Martin is aroused by Cecilia’s bland conversation and apparent feeble-mindedness but soon Cecilia’s detachment starts to obsess him and, unable to control his burgeoning neuroses, Martin’s life spins out of control. The enigmatic Cecilia, an inscrutable and monosyllabic presence to Martin’s excessive verbiage, exacerbates his feverous (and increasingly demonic) need to penetrate her calm. But Martin’s methods to destabilise Cecilia’s mystique are sexual violence and petty torments. Kahn’s roving camera, occasionally hand-held with sudden drops in lighting, suggests a documentary rather than a drama as he explores the futility of Martin’s masochistic irrationality. As a study of sexual obsession, “L’Ennui” pays detailed if detached attention to the sex act, deliberately failing to eroticise the couplings that at times appear utterly joyless to the protagonists. But at two hours and with a cyclical narrative, this film proves, at times, quite trying. Cast includes Charles Berling and Sophie Guillemin. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 31-33.
results.creator_credit: Michael Karris, Richard Jasek, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: In “Training for work” advice is given to sole parents who are thinking of rejoining the workforce. Particular attention is paid to the need for adequate childcare and retraining opportunities. The second episode “Driving safely” warns against irresponsible driving behaviour, especially drink- driving and speeding. In “Making job decisions” we follow young people making choices about the work they would like to do, as well as established workers attempting to retrain for different careers.

results.title: Enjoying Australasian wine
results.brief_description: The wine industries of Australia and New Zealand are producing wines of world class quality. To discover just how we are achieving this phenomenal success, we visit major wine growing areas in the two countries to hear from the growers and winemakers, followed by wine-tasting segments with Michael Hill-Smith, Australia’s only “Master of wine”. The areas visited are: the Hunter Valley and Mudgee, North-eastern Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and New Zealand. Introduced by Len Evans.

results.title: English without tears
results.creator_credit: Harold French, Sydney Box, William Sassoon, Anatole de Grunwald and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: Set in Geneva Switzerland during World War II “English without tears” is a gentle and entertaining romantic satire. The multi-plots within the film mainly focus on the small things that matter to people during wartime. An aristocratic family including an eccentric bird fancier (Margaret Rutherford) leaves for Geneva. The faithful butler joins the army and becomes lieutenant. The charming daughters falls for the butler who is successful in his new role. The plot becomes amusing as the story unfolds while the class barriers of peacetime relax and the romantic complications reveal themselves. A charming English studio film. Cast includes Michael Wilding, Margaret Rutherford, Lili Palmer and Penelope Ward.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 4-6.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Mark Sanders, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Episode four, “Being in a union”, is about the various functions performed by trade unions. In “Using public transport” a man used to driving everywhere finds that public transport can turn out to be much more convenient: but only once you can understand timetables and how to access information. And in “Using a phone” information is given on some of the barriers that inhibit people from using a phone effectively.

results.title: English at work. - Eps. 34-36.
results.creator_credit: Michael Karris, Richard Jasek, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: The final three episodes of the “English at work” series. In “Helping with problems” we are shown the various ways people can assist others by being good listeners and being prepared to stand up for the rights of others. In “Saving energy” we are shown ways to be more energy efficient at both work and home. “Preventing sexual harassment”. The prevention of sexual harassment and intimidation is shown to be the responsibility of management, workers, and unions: in fact every woman and man needs to object to the practice of harassment in their workplace whenever it occurs.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 28-30.
results.creator_credit: Michael Karris, Robert Bull, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Buying a car, new or used, can often be a stressful time because of the money involved. The first episode of this video details the importance of organising appropriate finance, being sure of exactly what kind of vehicle you need, and knowing what questions to ask dealers (be they a business or an individual) before buying your car. In “Deciding where to live” information is given on the various types of housing that exist in Australia - private, public, rental, home ownership and emergency housing. Episode 30, “Getting your skills recognised” explains the various services available for migrants to Australia to receive assistance in getting overseas qualifications recognised, and also explains how to arrange upgrading skills for the Australian workplace.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 25-27.
results.creator_credit: Mark Sanders, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: The first episode of this video demonstrates the need for safety precautions at work and at home, and in particular stresses the wearing of protective clothing. In “Building a home” a young couple is offered concise advice on what to do and what not to do when building your own house. The final episode, “Improving health and safety” stresses the necessity of clear, understandable information at the work place on health and safety - including the need for employers, unions and workers to ensure that health and safety information is accessible to all regardless of cultural or linguistic backgrounds.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 22-24.
results.creator_credit: Mandy Smith, Mark Sanders, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Episode 22, “Finding a place to live” examines the way that government agencies can assist people in selecting public or private accommodation. In “Voting” the Australian electoral system is explained and the importance of informed voting is debated. In “Making a new start” we are given a run-down on the new programs being introduced for unemployed people, particularly New Start and the Job Search Allowance.
